Saint Antoine Street W / Square-Victoria Street [http://www.stm.info/English/metro/Square-Victoria.pdf Square-Victoria Station Neighbourhood Map] |}} '''Square-Victoria''' is a [[metro station|station]] on the [[Line 2 Orange (Montreal Metro)|Orange Line]] of the [[Montreal Metro]] [[Rapid transit|rapid transit system]], operated by the [[SociÃ©tÃ© de transport de MontrÃ©al]] (STM). It is located in [[Victoria Square, Montreal|Victoria Square]] near the [[Quartier international de MontrÃ©al]] district, in the borough of [[Ville-Marie (Montreal)|Ville-Marie]] in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]].[http://www.stm.info/English/metro/a-m14.htm Square-Victoria Metro Station] The station opened on February 6, 1967, four months after most of the initial network, and was briefly the terminus of the orange line until [[Bonaventure (Montreal Metro)|Bonaventure]] station was opened a week later. == Overview == The metro station is a normal [[side platform]] station; its central [[Mezzanine (architecture)|mezzanine]] is connected to a very long [[tunnel]] running along Beaver Hall Hill and under [[Victoria Square, Montreal|Victoria Square]], giving access to its various exits. Each of the station's exits is connected to another building or buildings via the [[Underground city, Montreal|underground city]]. The Belmont exit is connected to and located in the 1080 Beaver Hall Hill building; the Viger exit is likewise connected to and located in the Bell Tower/National Bank complex. The [[Saint Antoine Street|Saint Antoine exit]] is a link in the main part of the underground city, linking the [[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]] building with the Centre CDP Capital, while the rotunda at the south end of the tunnel, leading to the [[Saint Jacques Street|Saint Jacques]] exit, links the [[Bourse de MontrÃ©al|Tour de la Bourse]] with the [[Centre de Commerce mondial de MontrÃ©al|Centre de commerce mondial]]. The station was designed by Irving Sager. Two steel [[mural]]s by [[Robert Savoie (artist)|Robert Savoie]], entitled ''Kawari Kabuto'', grace the walls of the great volume over the tunnel [[Vault (architecture)|vaults]], and a mural in the pedestrian tunnel to the northern entrances is by [[Jean-Paul Mousseau]]. The southern rotunda formerly contained a multimedia installation entitled ''Ars Natura'', promoting Montreal's science museums. [[Image:GuimardMon.JPG|thumb|left|Hector Guimard's entrance portico]] The most famous artwork, however, is one of [[Hector Guimard]]'s [[art nouveau]] entrance porticos from the [[Paris MÃ©tro]]. One of the few authentic installations on a metro station outside Paris, it was given in 1967 by the [[RÃ©gie Autonome des Transports Parisiens|RATP]] (RÃ©gie autonome des transports parisiens) to commemorate the collaboration of French and Canadian engineers in building the metro. It is located within Victoria Square on the Saint Antoine entrance, one of only four open-air entrances on the network (the others are located at [[Place-Saint-Henri (Montreal Metro)|Place-Saint-Henri]] and [[Bonaventure (Montreal Metro)|Bonaventure]] stations). It was recently removed, completely restored, and reinstalled. The station is equipped with the MÃ©troVision information screens which displays news, commercials, and the time till the next train. ==Origin of the name== This station is named for Victoria Square, which has existed since 1813; it was renamed for [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]] on the occasion of the visit of the Prince of Wales (later [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|King Edward VII]]) to Montreal in 1860. ==Connecting bus routes== {{Main|SociÃ©tÃ© de transport de MontrÃ©al}} {{Main|List of Montreal Bus Routes}}
